newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 15.36 pct.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 15.36 pct.

text.p: Yields on Venezuelan benchmark six-month TEM bills rose 73 basis points to 15.36 percent in Tuesday's auction, according to a calculation by Reuters that uses the Central Bank formula.

The Central Bank said it sold 60 billion bolivars of 180- day "monetary stabilization", or TEM, bills with a 14.63 percent coupon for a price of 99.66 pct. At last week's auction, the six-month notes yielded 14.63 percent.

The bank also sold 20 billion bolivars of 269-day notes with a 14.89 percent coupon at a price of 95.40 percent, and 20 billion bolivars of 358-day notes with a 15.16 percent coupon at an average price of 92.86 percent.
Yields for these notes rose 215 basis points to 22.06 percent for the 269-day bills, and 251 basis points to 24.06 percent for the 358-day TEMs.
The weekly TEM bill auctions are the Central Bank's principal tool of monetary policy, used to restrict liquidity and establish a benchmark for wider interest rates.
